name: Pinnacle
extraInfo: Director, Programmer, Artist. Created for GMTK Jam 2024. <bcr>Climb a mountain by building structures in a persistent environment.

elements.content:
Created in 96 hours for the GMTK Jam 2024.

I was the developer along with 1 composer.

With this game, I wanted to experiment with databases. To do so, I created a system where everything you build in the game is added to a database, which is loaded when opening the game. This allows all buildings in the game to persist and update in real time. You can see the routes past players have taken up the mountain, you can also see which areas are unexplored, and chart your own journey. Building has a relatively long cooldown, to force players to rely on other players for help.

elements.alt: Screenshot of objects table in Supabase.

elements.content: There is an OBJECTS table, where each row corresponds to a specific object. There is also a USERS table, used to store player's cooldowns. I used Supabase's c# library to interface with the database, using PostgreSQL commands to GET, and UPDATE when loading or building. Realtime updates are provided through Supabase's realtime service, allowing for other players builds to be added to your game as they happen, instead of just on an initial load.

For the arm animation animations, I used Unity's Animation Rigging Package to leverage procedural animation. The Hands are placed on the rocks using IK, finding a suitable position the correct distance from a hold, and setting their rotation to the normal of the hold's surface.

Each finger is then placed on the surface of the rock. A raycast if fired from each finger tip to a hint position near the palm. I then use IK to place the finger tip at the surface position each ray collides.

While the mountain generation itself wasn't entirely procedural, placing the handholds to allow for climbing on the mountain was. I created a tool that allows me to specify some simple parameters, like a noise map, density value, and prefab. It then steps through my terrain, using those factors and the steepness at the current location to create a fitness value. Handholds are then placed at each suitable location. Using my current settings, 18,317 hand holds are placed procedurally around the level. Doing this manually would not only be tedious and out of scope for a 96 hour jam, it would be a large pain in the wrist!

elements.alt: Screenshot of Prefab Placement tool window.
